titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Annie Dillard Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Friday May 3, 2019 at 03:01

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Annie Dillard Papers document the work and life of writer Annie Dillard. The papers consist of personal and professional correspondence, drafts of writings, notebooks and diaries, teaching materials, drawings, photographs, printed materials, audiovisual materials, computer disks, personal effects, and personal papers. The bulk of the collection consists of Dillard's writings and correspondence.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Annie Dillard, 1986, 1987, and 1989. Purchased from Glenn Horowitz Bookseller, Inc. on the Eugene G. O'Neill Memorial Fund, 2000; on the Elizabeth Wakeman Dwight Memorial Fund, 2004 and 2011. Purchased from Annie Dillard on the Danford N. Barney, Jr. Fund, 2013.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 52-53 are restricted.

Access to original audiovisual recordings is restricted pending reformatting. Access copies of select sound recordings for reference use are noted and available in the main files. Consult the Beinecke Library Access Services department for additional information.

Original computer disks are restricted. Copies of electronic files disks #1 (Uncat MSS 44) and #1-3 (Uncat ZA MS 90) are available through Access Services. System requirements include CD/DVD drive and file viewing software.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Annie Dillard Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Annie Dillard Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

This collection received preliminary processing at the time of acquisition in 1986, 1987, 1989, 2000 and 2004. Further organization, rehousing and/or description was carried out in 2010. The collection is comprised of material formerly classed as Uncat ZA MS 14, Uncat MS 83, Uncat MS 90, Uncat MSS 44, Uncat MSS 64, and Uncat MSS 695. Various acquisitions associated with the collection have not been merged and organized as a whole. Each acquisition is described separately in the contents list below, according to month and year of acquisition.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial and subsequent processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

bioghist.head: Annie Dillard, 1945-
bioghist.p: Annie Dillard was born Meta Ann Doak on April 30, 1945 in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. She attended Hollins College near Roanoke, Virginia, and studied creative writing and religion. In her sophomore year, she married her creative writing professor, Richard Dillard, who had a strong influence on her writing. Dillard finished her undergraduate degree in English literature and completed a Masters in Fine Arts from Hollins, in 1968.

After graduate school, Dillard spent her time writing poetry and short stories, some of which she published, and painting and drawing. Interested in the region around her suburban home, filled with forests, mountains, creek, and animals, she wrote about her experiences and observations of area in journals that would become her first book, Pilgrim at Tinker Creek . Published in 1974, the book won Dillard the Pulitzer Prize in 1975 at the age of 29. Dillard divorced her first husband and she moved to Washington state for the position of writer in residence at Western Washington University. She married professor Gary Clevidence and had a daughter. Dillard published Holy the Firm , the memoir An American Chilhood , and two novels, The Living and The Maytrees . She was a professor in the department of English at Wesleyan University in Middletown, CT and now lives in Hillsborough, North Carolina and Wythe County, Virginia with her third husband, professor and writer Robert Richardson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Annie Dillard Papers document the work and life of writer Annie Dillard. The papers consist of personal and professional correspondence, drafts of writings, notebooks and diaries, teaching materials, drawings, photographs, printed materials, audiovisual materials, computer disks, personal effects, and personal papers, spanning the years 1955-2000. The bulk of the collection consists of Dillard's writings drafts and correspondence. Writings shed light on her creative process and include handwritten and typescript drafts and printed versions of writings, including her books An American Childhood, The Living and Pilgrim at Tinker Creek . Correspondence includes letters from friends, colleagues and readers regarding her writings, both in the publishing process and after publication.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into eight groupings: I. April 1986 Acquisition, 1965-1984. II. August 1987 Acquisition, undated. III. February 1989 Acquisition, 1983-1987. IV. May 2000 Acquisition, 1955-2000. V. May 2000 Acquisition, 1999-2000. VI. August 2004 Acquisition, 1991-1992. VII. January 2011 Acquisition, 1960s-2010. VIII. May 2013 Acquisition, 1987-2012.

odd.p: Formerly classified as Uncat ZA MSS 14.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Regarding portions of Pilgrim at Tinker Creek published in Sojourners , Connell , Atlantic Monthly , Poetry Review , Prose , and Harper's . Includes correspondence with Buckminster Fuller, Libby Thayer, and Gregory Blanche; and rejection letters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs taken by Gordon Converse of The Christian Science Monitor during trip Dillard made for a story. Photographs are black and white images of Dillard; people and various animals in the jungle of Ecuador; and unidentified male.
Includes two March 1975 letters to Dillard from Converse and clippings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in nine series: Correspondence, Writings, Notebooks, Teaching Materials, Writings of Others, Drawings, Printed Material on Dillard, Other Papers and Objects, Audiovisual Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of correspondence with various individuals; handwritten, typescript, photocopies and proofs of writings by Dillard; notebooks kept by Dillard in coursework and as part of her creative process; writings by other sent to Dillard for review; drawings made by Dillard; printed material, including magazines, journals and clippings on Dillard; sound recordings and videotapes containing Dillard reading or appearing on radio and television programming; and a small amount of personal effects and papers.
Formerly classified as Uncat MSS 44.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by folder titles assigned by Dillard.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged into three headings: drafts, printed versions, and student papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This acquisition consists of notebooks; drafts of many works, including Love and Free Time , and The Maytrees ; correspondence, including Gary Clevidence, Blanche Gregory, Rollie McKenna, various friends, and fan mail; personal papers including calendars, clippings, and packing lists; miscellaneous audiovisual materials, and electronic computer files.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in the order as numbered by Annie Dillard, equating to a rough chronological order.
